author: Jules Verne
title: Around the World in Eighty Days

Phileas Fogg.reason: He is a man of routine, so he is content with his daily habit thus far, but there is no indication of his emotions to suggest a higher score.
Fogg seems content with his life and his new valet, but also seems to be a bit of a rigid and solitary person.
Pleased with the prospect of the wager, but not overly excited.
He is calm, collected, and ready to embark on his journey despite the criticism he faces.
He might be feeling confident about his ability to complete the journey on time, but the recent telegraphic dispatch about him being found as a bank robber could be a cause for concern.
Fogg seems neutral, focused on his mission.
Fogg seems to be his usual emotionless self, neither happy nor unhappy.
He appears to be calm and focused on his journey, but his reaction to Passepartout's loss of his package suggests he is not entirely happy.
He confidently adapts to the obstacle of the unfinished railway and has a plan to make up for lost time.
Although he has paid a high price for the elephant, he has succeeded in securing the transportation he needs to win the bet.
Although he suggests saving Aouda, his emotions are not fully revealed and he seems calm and calculated as usual.
He remains calm and collected, despite the chaos of the situation.
Fogg is successful in rescuing Aouda and offering to escort her to Hong Kong, achieving his goal of arriving within the allotted time frame.
Although he was sentenced to a week's imprisonment and a fine of one hundred and fifty pounds, he remained self-composed and offered bail right away.
Neutral, as there is no indication of his emotional state in this section.
Fogg is feeling content with the progress of his journey, having gained half a day on the prescribed time of arrival in Singapore.
He is slightly behind schedule but remains calm and collected, maintaining his usual tranquillity.
He is not mentioned in this section of the story.
Fogg is neutral and patient as always, but he has just experienced a setback in his journey.
Fogg seems calm and focused, but there is no clear indication of his emotions.

Fogg seems confident as he is due to arrive at Shanghai that evening, but his whole fortune is at stake if they miss the steamer to Yokohama that is leaving at the appointed time. He remains calm despite this.
Not mentioned in this section of the story.
He is relieved to learn that Passepartout has arrived and they can leave for San Francisco that evening but is likely reserved in showing too much emotion.
Fogg is relieved to have overcome the difficult part of his journey and is now making good time towards his goal.
He is cautious and perhaps a little annoyed since he wants to get on with his journey but is caught in the political meeting.
While Fogg is still determined to catch his ship in New York on time, he is calm and collected during the train journey.
He is not mentioned in this part of the story, so it's hard to tell how he feels.
He is glad to be able to play whist to pass the time on the train.
He is absorbed in his game of whist and not paying attention to the delay or the danger of crossing the bridge.

He is in a hurry to get back to Europe and any delay will be greatly to his disadvantage, but he has just been in a duel that was interrupted by an attack by Sioux; therefore, his state of mind may not be the happiest right now.
He has made the decision to risk his life to rescue his servant, showing a sense of duty and courage.
He managed to save himself and the other travelers from the Sioux, found an alternate mode of transportation and seems to be making up lost time.
He has found an alternative way to complete his journey, but the cost is much higher than he anticipated.
Fogg is calm, but his plan to burn the upper part of the Henrietta shows that he is feeling a little stressed and under pressure.
He has just been cleared of criminal charges, but he lost the bet and is now ruined.
He seems to be calm and collected but also saddened by his recent loss of fortune.
Fogg has won his wager and is finally married to the woman he loves; he is bound to be very happy.

Jean Passepartout.reason: He seems excited to have found his ideal master in Phileas Fogg and has accepted the job offer, but there is still uncertainty about how things will turn out.
Passepartout is excited and happy to have finally found a master that suits him, and is satisfied with the living arrangements.
Neutral, as he has just joined Phileas Fogg's service and is not yet sure what to expect.
He is confused and overwhelmed by his master's sudden decision to leave and the hasty packing process.
Same as Phileas Fogg.
Despite some worry about his burner, Passepartout seems excited and curious about their journey.
Passepartout is enjoying the trip, is well-fed and well-lodged, and is pleased to find Fix on board.
He is hatless, shoeless, and has lost his package of shirts and shoes, leaving him crestfallen.
He is worried about delays and the possibility of having caused Mr. Fogg to lose the bet.
He is worried about the future of the elephant, but also seems impressed with his master's determination to win the bet at any cost.
He shows compassion for Aouda and is ready to assist in her rescue, but also expresses anger and disgust towards the barbaric Indian customs.
He is happy and proud of his success in saving Aouda's life.
Passepartout is happy to see Aouda recovered and to offer Kiouni to the guide, but may be a bit disappointed to leave India so quickly.
He is stupefied and angry and knows that his mistake cost his master a lot of money.
Content, as he seems happy to reunite with Detective Fix and enjoys a friendly drink with him.
Passepartout is amused by Fix's continued attempts to follow Fogg but is frustrated by the weather and delays caused by the defective construction of the "Rangoon."
He is enraged and in a fury due to the unpropitious weather that is causing delays in their journey and is longing to lash the sea into obedience.
He is feeling conflicted between his loyalty to his master and his concern for the situation he has been made aware of.
Passepartout does not appear in this section of the story.
Passepartout is not mentioned in this section of the story.

Passepartout wakes up in a confused state, realizing he had been drugged, and that they missed the steamer to Yokohama, which he takes responsibility for; he becomes calmer but remains unsure of his future.
He is lost and hungry, but has found a way to blend in with the local culture and is determined to find a way out of Japan.
He has found employment and is happy to have a purpose, but he may still feel conflicted about his costume and participating in the show.
Passepartout is joyful to have proof that his watch was accurate and is also happy to have had a chance to get revenge on Fix.
He is curious and surprised by what he sees in the streets of San Francisco, but not really affected emotionally.
Passepartout is initially irritated by the cold and the snow, and later grows increasingly frustrated by the delay caused by the buffalo, but ultimately goes to bed and falls asleep.
He seems interested in Mormonism and attending the lecture, but also seems relieved to leave the car when it's over.
He is impatient due to the difficult terrain they are facing, but is also relieved that they've got Mr. Fogg to stay in the train by playing cards.
He is terrified and angry at the danger posed by crossing the bridge.
While he did not disappear like some of the other passengers, he still went through a frightening ordeal and helped save the train, so he may be neutral for now.
He has not been mentioned in this section of the story.
He managed to survive an intense confrontations with the Sioux and is now back on track to reach New York on time.
He thinks Mr. Fogg's maneuver is "simply glorious."
Although Passepartout is still enthusiastic about his master's journey, he has become increasingly worried as the coal runs out and the ship starts to pitch in the waves.
He is happy that his master has been cleared of charges, but he knows that they have lost the bet and that Mr. Fogg is ruined.
He is full of remorse and guilt, unable to forgive himself for his part in Mr. Fogg's loss.
Passepartout saved Aouda and gave her away at her wedding, which must have left him feeling very happy.
